item.title: Warning UK could be entering early stages of third wave
item.description: A scientist advising the government says there has been exponential growth in the number of new cases.

item.title: China allows couples to have three children
item.description: Census results show China's population grew at its slowest pace in decades last year.

item.title: UK set for stronger post-Covid recovery, says OECD
item.description: The UK economy's post-pandemic performance will outpace other large rich nations, a new forecast says.

item.title: France fugitive caught after shoot-out with Dordogne police
item.description: An armed ex-soldier is shot and wounded after a 24-hour manhunt in south-west France.

item.title: In pictures: Bank Holiday Monday brings hottest day of the year
item.description: After weeks of gloomy weather, people made the most of the warmer temperatures over the long weekend.

item.title: NSA spying row: Denmark accused of helping US spy on European officials
item.description: Denmark's secret service is accused of helping the US target politicians such as Germany's Angela Merkel.

item.title: Covid: Vietnam starts mass testing as new variant emerges
item.description: A Covid outbreak in Ho Chi Minh City triggers new social distancing rules and mass testing.

item.title: Israel coalition government a threat to security, warns Netanyahu
item.description: The prime minister urges right-wing politicians not to join a proposed new unity government.

item.title: Dog buried alive and left for dead
item.description: Passing hillwalkers heard the collie's cries and found Jake had been deliberately buried under a pile of rocks.

item.title: Pilot distracted by passenger wanting to fly, report says
item.description: A pilot may have been distracted by a passenger "constantly asking to try to fly the aircraft", a report says.

item.title: Pin Mill boat rescue: Diners rescued as floating restaurant gets stuck
item.description: The vessel's engines failed and it got lodged on mud near Pin Mill, Suffolk, with 11 people onboard.

item.title: A Quiet Place Part II becomes biggest pandemic-era US box office hit
item.description: The film becomes the biggest hit at North American box offices since the start of the pandemic.

item.title: HBO Max outage in US mars Mare of Easttown finale
item.description: Kate Winslet's drama reaches its "masterpiece" last episode, but many US viewers are made to wait.

item.title: War Horse actor salutes 80s gay Soho in one-man show
item.description: Jack Holden's play tells the story of a man diagnosed with HIV who decides to party his last days away.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Jabs 'ramped up' and Covid passport 'scrapped'
item.description: The vaccination programme and plans for Covid status certificates make the front pages of the papers.

item.title: Uganda: Finding the truth behind a killing spree in Kampala
item.description: BBC finds evidence Ugandan security forces killed unarmed people during a crackdown in November 2020.

item.title: James Barnor: The 91-year-old's photos bringing Ghana to life
item.description: Ghanaian-British photographer James Barnor's work is being exhibited at the Serpentine Gallery in London.

item.title: South Korea: From food wasters to recyclers
item.description: The country now recycles more than 95% of its food waste - how did they do it?

item.title: Tulsa Race Massacre: What happened in 1921?
item.description: Exactly 100 years ago the city in Oklahoma saw one of the biggest race massacres in US history.

item.title: Seal with bin bag wrapped round neck freed into wild
item.description: The seal was found at Walton-on-the-Naze in Essex with an "horrific" injury.

item.title: Metal, money, mystery: How Sanjeev Gupta built his empire
item.description: The UK helped metals tycoon Sanjeev Gupta save the country's last smelter. It was a lucrative deal.

item.title: Coronavirus: The Indian children orphaned by Covid-19
item.description: Officially, hundreds of children have lost both their parents. Experts say the number may be much higher.

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: Are businesses really tackling racial inequality?
item.description: Are businesses doing enough to tackle racial inequalities in the boardroom and workplace?

item.title: Noisy appliances: How loud is your house?
item.description: Environmental consultancy Quiet Mark is on a mission to ensure technology is seen but barely heard.

item.title: Biosecurity warning over loosely-regulated virus labs
item.description: Governments do not have controls to stop terrorists accessing labs and posing a biological threat.

item.title: Carrie Johnson: Who is the prime minister's wife?
item.description: Boris Johnson married Carrie Symonds, the mother of his baby son, at Westminster Cathedral on 29 May 2021 - but what else is known about her?

item.title: Man City striker Aguero to join Barcelona on two-year deal
item.description: Sergio Aguero will join Barcelona on a two-year contract when his Manchester City contract expires at the end of June.

item.title: Real Madrid 'no longer had faith in me' - Zidane
item.description: Zinedine Zidane says he resigned from Real Madrid because he felt the club "no longer had faith" in him.

item.title: Sacked by Yorkshire, picked by England - meet Ollie Robinson
item.description: Pace bowler Ollie Robinson on being sacked, why his mum is nicknamed 'Richie Benaud' and how his dad beat him to an international call-up.

item.title: Copa America without host 13 days before start as Argentina stripped of tournament
item.description: The 2021 Copa America has been left without a host less than two weeks before it starts after Argentina was stripped of the tournament.

item.title: NBA: LeBron James' no-look assist as LA Lakers lose to Phoenix Suns
item.description: LeBron James provides a no-look backward pass assist as the Los Angeles Lakers fall to a 100-92 defeat by the Phoenix Suns in the NBA play-offs.

item.title: Your guide to Spain, Portugal and other holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: How are eviction rules for renters and landlords changing?
item.description: The eviction ban is ending, but what does that mean?

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: People are now being told to minimise travel to eight areas of England where Covid is spreading fast.

item.title: Children tell of neglect, filth and fear in US asylum camps
item.description: The BBC has uncovered allegations of cold temperatures, sickness, lice and abuse, through a series of interviews with children and staff at US detention camps for children.

item.title: Rafael Nadal: The 'tough love' that shaped a 20-time Grand Slam champion
item.description: From 'scaredy cat' to a 'raging bull', Rafael Nadal's transformation into a true tennis great has a lot to do with one man in particular.

item.title: Martin Bashir inquiry: Diana, the reporter and the BBC
item.description: The full story of how the BBC's Martin Bashir got his 1995 interview with Princess Diana - and what happened next.
